case_name: V. N. Sarin v. Ajit Kumar Poplai

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 468 of 1965 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 1. 1965 of the Punjab High Court at Delhi in Second Appeal from Order No. 235/D of 1963.

facts.text: Punjab High Court judgment and order dated March 1, 1965 in Second Appeal from Order No. 235/D of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 1. 1965 of the Punjab High Court at Delhi in Second Appeal from Order No. 235/D of 1963. Parushottam Trikamdas and D. Goburdhan, for the appellant.

facts.text: Premises are part of bungalow at Racquet Court Road, Civil Lines, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The premises in question are a part of a bungalow situate at Racquet Court Road, Civil Lines, Delhi. The bungalow originally belonged to the joint Hindu family consisting of respondent No. 2, Mr. B. S. Poplai and his two sons, respondent No. 1, Major Ajit Kumar Poplai and Vinod Kumar Poplai.

facts.text: Bungalow originally belonged to joint Hindu family consisting of respondent No. 2 Mr. B. S. Poplai and his two sons respondent No. 1 Major Ajit Kumar Poplai and Vinod Kumar Poplai.

anchor.surface_text: The bungalow originally belonged to the joint Hindu family consisting of respondent No. 2, Mr. B. S. Poplai and his two sons, respondent No. 1, Major Ajit Kumar Poplai and Vinod Kumar Poplai. The three members of this undivided Hindu family partitioned their coparcenary property on May 17, 1962,

facts.text: Joint family partitioned coparcenary property on May 17, 1962, premises fell to share of respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: The three members of this undivided Hindu family partitioned their coparcenary property on May 17, 1962, and as a result of the said partition, the present premises fell to the share of respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Appellant V. N. Sarin inducted as tenant by respondent No. 2 before partition at monthly rent of Rs. 80.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant V. N. Sarin had been inducted into the premises as a tenant by respondent No. 2 before partition at a monthly rental of Rs. 80. After respondent No. 1 got this property by partition,

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 applied to Rent Controller for eviction of appellant on ground of bona fide requirement for own residence and family.

anchor.surface_text: After respondent No. 1 got this property by partition, he applied to the Rent Controller for the eviction of the appellant on the ground that he required the premises bona fide for his own residence and that of his wife and children who are dependent on him.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 impleaded appellant and respondent No. 2 in eviction application.

anchor.surface_text: To this application, he impleaded the appellant and respondent No. 2. The appellant contested the claim of respondent No. 1 of three grounds.

facts.text: Appellant contested eviction claiming unawareness of partition and that respondent No. 1 not landlord.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contested the claim of respondent No. 1 of three grounds. He urged that respondent No. 1 was not his landlord inasmuch as he was not aware of the partition and did not know what it contained.

facts.text: Appellant claimed respondent No. 1 did not require premises bona fide under s.14(1)(e).

anchor.surface_text: He also urged that even if respondent No. 1 was his landlord, he did not require the premises bona fide and so, the requirements of s. 14 (1) (e) of the Act were not satisfied.

facts.text: Appellant claimed partition is acquisition by transfer under s.14(6), making suit incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: The last contention raised by him was that if respondent No. 1 got the property in suit by partition, in law it meant that he had acquired the premises by transfer within the meaning of s. 14 (6) of the Act and the provisions of the said section make the present suit incompetent.

facts.text: Rent Controller held respondent No. 1 exclusive owner and landlord by partition.

anchor.surface_text: The Rent Controller held that respondent No. 1 was the exclusive owner of the premises in suit by virtue of partition. As such, it was found that he was the landlord of the appellant.

facts.text: Rent Controller rejected respondent No. 1's bona fide need under s.14(1)(e).

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the plea made by respondent No. 1 that he needed the premises bona fide as prescribed by s. 14 (1) (e), the Rent Controller rejected the case of respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Rent Controller held partition not acquisition by transfer under s.14(6).

anchor.surface_text: The point raised by the appellant under s. 14 (6) of the Act was not upheld on the ground that acquisition of the suit premises by partition cannot be said to be acquisition by transfer within the meaning of the said section.

facts.text: Rent Controller dismissed eviction application due to rejection of bona fide need.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the finding recorded against respondent No. 1 under s. 14 (1) (e) however, his application for the appellants eviction failed.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 appealed to Rent Control Tribunal, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision, respondent No. 1 preferred an appeal to the Rent Control Tribunal, Delhi. The said Tribunal agreed with the Rent Controller in holding that respondent No. 1 was the landlord of the premises in suit and had not acquired the said premises by transfer.

facts.text: Rent Control Tribunal held respondent No. 1 landlord and not acquired by transfer.

anchor.surface_text: The said Tribunal agreed with the Rent Controller in holding that respondent No. 1 was the landlord of the premises in suit and had not acquired the said premises by transfer.

facts.text: Rent Control Tribunal accepted respondent No. 1's bona fide need under s.14(1)(e).

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the finding recorded by the, Rent Controller under s. 14 (1) (e), the Rent Control Tribunal came to a different conclusion. It held that respondent No.1 had established his case that he needed the premises bona fide for his personal use as prescribed by the said provision.

facts.text: Rent Control Tribunal allowed appeal and ordered eviction of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal preferred by respondent No. 1 was allowed and the eviction of the appellant was ordered.

facts.text: Appellant filed second appeal to Punjab High Court challenging the decision.

anchor.surface_text: This decision was challenged by the appellant by preferring a second appeal before the Punjab High Court. The High Court upheld the findings recorded by the Rent Control Tribunal on the question of the status of respondent No. 1 as the landlord of the premises

facts.text: Punjab High Court upheld Tribunal findings on landlord status and bona fide need.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court upheld the findings recorded by the Rent Control Tribunal on the question of the status of respondent No. 1 as the landlord of the premises and on the plea made by him that his claim for eviction of the appellant was justified under s. 14 (1) (e).

facts.text: Punjab High Court held partition not acquisition by transfer under s.14(6).

anchor.surface_text: The main contention which was raised before the High Court was in regard to the construction of s. 14 (6) and on this point, the High Court has agreed with the view taken by the Rent Control Tribunal and has held that respondent No. 1 cannot be said to have acquired the premises in suit by transfer within the meaning of the said section.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave against High Court decree.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this decree that the appellant has come to this Court by special leave. Mr. Purshottam for the appellant argues that the view taken by the High Court about the construction of s. 14 (6) is erroneous in law.

facts.text: All courts below found respondent No. 1 is landlord of premises.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found by all the courts below that respondent No. 1 is a landlord of the premises and this position has not been and cannot be disputed in the appeal before us.

facts.text: Rent Control Tribunal and High Court found bona fide need established by respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: The Rent Control Tribunal and the High Court have recorded a finding against the appellant and in favour of respondent No. 1 on this point and this finding also has not been and cannot be challenged before us.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 1. 1965 of the Punjab High Court at Delhi in Second Appeal from Order No. 235/D of 1963.

holdings.text: Respondent No. 1 is a landlord of the premises.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found by all the courts below that respondent No. 1 is a landlord of the premises and this position has not been and cannot be disputed in the appeal before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings by Rent Controller, Tribunal, and High Court accepted as undisputed.

holdings.text: Respondent No. 1 has established bona fide requirement of the premises for personal use under s. 14(1)(e).

anchor.surface_text: The Rent Control Tribunal and the High Court have recorded a finding against the appellant and in favour of respondent No. 1 on this point and this finding also has not been and cannot be challenged before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Findings by Rent Control Tribunal and High Court (reversing Rent Controller) accepted as undisputed.

holdings.text: Partition of coparcenary property resulting in allotment to respondent No. 1 does not constitute acquisition by transfer within the meaning of s. 14(6).

anchor.surface_text: The short question of law which arises in this appeal is whether the partition of the coparcenary property among the coparceners can be said to be an acquisition by transfer within the meaning of s. 14 6  of the Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958  Act No. 59 of 1958   hereinafter called the Act .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Coparcener has antecedent title transformed from joint to specific by partition, not new title by transfer; s.14(6) targets strangers acquiring via transfer to evade eviction restrictions; distinguished TPA s.53, Registration Act; followed Girja Bal (no new title created) and CIT v. Keshavlal (partition not transfer).

holdings.text: Section 14(6) is intended to prevent landlords from transferring premises to purchasers as a device to circumvent eviction restrictions under s.14(1)(e).

anchor.surface_text: Before construing s. 14 (6), it may be permissible to enquire what may be the policy underlying the section and the object intended to be achieved by it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive construction based on legislative policy against evasion via transfers enabling new landlords to claim bona fide need.

anchor.surface_text: The short question of law which arises in this appeal is whether the partition of the coparcenary property among the coparceners can be said to be an acquisition by transfer within the meaning of s. 14 6  of the Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958  Act No. 59 of 1958   hereinafter called the Act .

The short question of law which arises in this appeal is whether the partition of the coparcenary property among the coparceners can be said to be an acquisition by transfer within the meaning of s. 14 6  of the Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958  Act No. 59 of 1958   hereinafter called the Act .
Before construing s. 14 (6), it may be permissible to enquire what may be the policy underlying the section and the object intended to be achieved by it.
